title: Morgan Stanley Tops Q1 Estimates on Record Equities Trading Revenue
snippets:
Morgan Stanley (MS) posted better-than-expected first-quarter results on the back of record stock-trading revenue amid volatile markets.

The bank reported earnings per share (EPS) of $2.60 on record revenue of $17.74 billion. Analysts polled by Visible Alpha had expected $2.18 and $16.44 billion, respectively. 

Morgan Stanley's results were powered by equity revenue that soared 45% year-over-year to a record $4.13 billion. The bank said it posted "increases across business lines and regions, particularly in Asia, with outperformance in prime brokerage and derivatives driven by strong client activity amid a more volatile trading environment."

Morgan Stanley shares were down about 1% in recent trading but have risen more than 20% in the past 12 months.
summary: Morgan Stanley reported first-quarter earnings surpassing expectations with an EPS of $2.60 and record revenue of $17.74 billion, against analysts' predictions of $2.18 EPS and $16.44 billion in revenue. The bank's equity revenue jumped 45% year-over-year to $4.13 billion, attributed to strong performance across all business lines and regions, especially in Asia, driven by prime brokerage and derivatives amid volatile markets. Despite the positive results, Morgan Stanley shares dropped about 1% in recent trading, though they have increased over 20% in the last year.
titles: Morgan Stanley Tops Q1 Estimates on Record Equities Trading Revenue

title: Newmont and Other Miner Stocks Pop as Gold Keeps Hitting Record Highs
snippets:
Shares of Newmont (NEM) and other miners surged Friday, while the price of gold climbed to fresh highs as investors flocked to safe haven assets amid economic uncertainty. 

The price of gold was up over 2% Friday to a record $3,248.20 per ounce, topping highs set just a day earlier. Shares of gold miner Newmont jumped nearly 8%, propelling it to lead gains on the S&P 500, extending its rally earlier this week. Other miner stocks including Barrick Gold (GOLD), Kinross Gold (KGC), and Gold Fields (GFI) also rose. 

Traditionally viewed as a safe haven asset, investors have piled into gold in recent weeks as worries about President Donald Trump's rapidly shifting trade policies rattle markets, sending the precious metal’s price up more than 20% since the start of the year. 

The S&P 500 was slightly lower in recent trading after some of the world’s largest banks, including JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC), reported better-than-expected earnings but warned President Donald Trump's tariffs could slow economic growth. (Read Investopedia's live coverage of today's market action here.)
summary: Shares of Newmont and other gold miners surged as the price of gold reached a new record of $3,248.20 per ounce, driven by investors seeking safe haven assets amid economic uncertainty. This increase, over 2% on Friday, follows a trend of rising gold prices, up more than 20% since the beginning of the year, attributed to concerns over President Donald Trump's trade policies. Newmont's stock jumped nearly 8%, leading gains on the S&P 500. Other miners like Barrick Gold, Kinross Gold, and Gold Fields also saw their shares rise. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 dipped slightly after banks like JPMorgan Cha
titles: Newmont and Other Miner Stocks Pop as Gold Keeps Hitting Record Highs

title: US Chip Firms Outsourcing Manufacturing Exempted From China’s Tariffs Against US
snippets:
China on Friday said U.S. chip firms outsourcing manufacturing would be exempt from the country’s tariffs on U.S. goods, according to a notice on WeChat. 

The post by the China Semiconductor Industry Association indicated that for all integrated circuits, import customs would be based on the country where they were manufactured, according to a Google translation.

That means, for example, that chips purchased by Chinese firms from American companies like Nvidia (NVDA)—which outsources manufacturing to TSMC (TSM) in Taiwan—would not be subject to China’s tariffs on U.S. goods. On Friday, China hiked its tariffs on U.S. imports to 125% after President Donald Trump elevated U.S. duties on Chinese goods to 145%.

However, American companies that manufacture domestically like Texas Instruments (TXN) and Intel (INTC) would still see China's tariffs apply to those chips made in the U.S.

Shares of Texas Instruments plunged over 8% in recent trading following the news, making it the worst-performing stock in the S&P 500. Shares of Intel also tumbled, while Nvidia and TSMC gained. (Read Investopedia's live coverage of today's market action here.)
summary: China announced that U.S. chip companies that outsource their manufacturing will not be subject to the country's tariffs on U.S. goods. This exemption applies to chips made outside the U.S., benefiting firms like Nvidia, which manufactures through TSMC in Taiwan. Conversely, American companies producing chips domestically, such as Texas Instruments and Intel, will face China's tariffs. This decision comes after China raised its tariffs on U.S. imports to 125% in response to the U.S. increasing duties on Chinese goods to 145%. Following the announcement, shares of Texas Instruments significantl
titles: US Chip Firms Outsourcing Manufacturing Exempted From China’s Tariffs Against US

title: Trump tariffs could push US inflation to 4% this year, warns top Fed official
snippets: President’s trade war likely to raise unemployment and slow economic growth ‘considerably’, says John Williams
summary: John Williams, an economic expert, has stated that the President's trade war is expected to significantly increase unemployment rates and decelerate economic growth. This assessment provides a clear outlook on the potential economic consequences of the ongoing trade policies.
titles: Trump tariffs could push US inflation to 4% this year, warns top Fed official

title: Here's What Big Bank CEOs Are Saying About Tariffs and the Economy
snippets:
Key Takeaways

  • Executives from across the banking industry gave their thoughts on tariffs and the current uncertainty and volatility dominating the stock market.
  • JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon said he expects many companies to adjust or pull their full-year outlooks considering the uncertainty.
  • BlackRock CEO Larry Fink said the tariffs "went beyond anything I could have imagined."


Executives from across the banking industry spoke on Friday about the uncertainty surrounding the Trump administration's tariffs, the stock market, and the possibility of a recession.

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon said he expects more companies to suspend their full-year guidance amid the uncertainty, something Delta Air Lines (DAL) and CarMax (KMX) did this week.

"You're going to hear 1,000 companies report, and they're going to tell you what their guidance is. My guess [is] a lot will remove it," Dimon said. "They're going to tell you what they think it might do to their customers, their base, their earnings, their costs, their tariffs. It's different for every company, but I assume you see that."

Tariffs 'Went Beyond Anything I Could Have Imagined,' BlackRock's Fink Says

BlackRock (BLK) CEO Larry Fink said in Friday's earnings call that last week's tariff announcement "went beyond anything I could have imagined in my 49 years in finance," according to a transcript from AlphaSense.

Fink also said that despite uncertainty around tariffs dominating the headlines, other "macro forces" like artificial intelligence, rising demand for energy and infrastructure, and the potential for de-regulation under the Trump administration are "just as strong today" as they were earlier this year.

Wells Fargo CEO Scharf Sees 'Risks' With Tariffs

"We support the administration's willingness to look at barriers to fair trade for the United States, though there are certainly risks associated with such significant actions," Wells Fargo (WFC) CEO Charlie Scharf said in Friday's earnings release. Scharf added that the bank expects "continued volatility and uncertainty and are prepared for a slower economic environment in 2025, but the actual outcome will be dependent on the results and timing of the policy changes."

Bank of New York Mellon (BK) CEO Robin Vince noted that the firm is "prepared for a wide range of macroeconomic and market scenarios as the outlook for the operating environment is becoming more uncertain."
summary: Banking industry executives, including JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon and BlackRock CEO Larry Fink, expressed concerns over the uncertainty and volatility in the stock market due to the Trump administration's tariffs. Dimon expects many companies to withdraw their full-year financial outlooks amid this uncertainty, a move already made by companies like Delta Air Lines and CarMax. Fink described the recent tariff announcements as unprecedented in his nearly five decades in finance. Additionally, Wells Fargo CEO Charlie Scharf acknowledged risks associated with the tariffs but noted the bank is
titles: Here's What Big Bank CEOs Are Saying About Tariffs and the Economy

title: Methane-eating bacteria are ready to capture landfill emissions
snippets: Bioreactors housing methane-eating bacteria could offer a portable, off-grid solution for soaking up methane leaks from sites like landfills and coal mines
summary: Researchers have developed portable bioreactors that use methane-eating bacteria to absorb methane emissions from sources such as landfills and coal mines. This innovative solution presents an off-grid method for reducing methane leaks, a potent greenhouse gas, from various industrial sites.
titles: Methane-eating bacteria are ready to capture landfill emissions

title: Driving the CAR to fight acute myeloid leukemia
snippets: A multi-institutional team developed a chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell-based strategy for specifically targeting AML cells in patients who relapsed following other treatments. The team identified a monoclonal antibody called KG2032 that reacts with a certain variant of the HLA-DRB1 molecule. KG2032 CAR T cells displayed strong anti-AML effects in a mouse model, and CAR natural killer cells showed similar results. Clinical trials are currently being planned.
summary: A team from multiple institutions developed a new treatment targeting acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells in patients who relapsed after previous treatments. They discovered a monoclonal antibody, KG2032, that targets a variant of the HLA-DRB1 molecule. In mouse models, KG2032 CAR T cells demonstrated significant anti-AML effects, with CAR natural killer cells showing similar outcomes. Clinical trials for this treatment are now in the planning stages.
titles: Driving the CAR to fight acute myeloid leukemia

title: From boring to bursting: Giant black hole awakens
snippets: Astronomers are investigating the longest and most energetic bursts of X-rays seen from a newly awakened black hole. Watching this strange behavior unfold in real time offers a unique opportunity to learn more about these powerful events and the mysterious behavior of massive black holes.
summary: Astronomers have observed the longest and most energetic X-ray bursts ever recorded from a newly awakened black hole. This unprecedented phenomenon provides a rare chance to study the intense events and enigmatic nature of massive black holes in greater detail.
titles: From boring to bursting: Giant black hole awakens

title: Dolphins are dying from toxic chemicals banned since the 1980s
snippets: Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) are commonly found in the bodies of short-beaked common dolphins that get stranded on UK beaches, and are linked to the animals’ risk of infectious diseases
summary: Studies have found that short-beaked common dolphins stranded on UK beaches often contain high levels of Polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), chemicals linked to an increased risk of infectious diseases in these animals.
titles: Dolphins are dying from toxic chemicals banned since the 1980s
